response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms a human subject seated at a workbench, with the robot end-effector located closely at the person's neck region. The end-effector appears positioned to interact with the back and sides of the neck, which is supported by the relative proximity and orientation of the wrist frame. The neck/contact area is soft-tissue, cylindrical, and compliant, requiring controlled moderate force to avoid discomfort or injury. The workspace is indoors with stable ground and no obstructions directly around the neck region. The robot's wrist is very close to the neck and angled slightly downward and forward, which matches the natural neck curvature and facilitates precise interaction.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such:  
- The red wrist X-axis points roughly horizontally rightward and slightly outward relative to the robot base, paralleling the horizontal right in the world frame from the camera's perspective.  
- The green wrist Y-axis points roughly diagonally upward and slightly backward relative to the wrist, corresponding roughly to upward and backward world directions.  
- The blue wrist Z-axis points roughly forward and slightly upward from the wrist, matching forward motion into the workspace camera view with a minor upward tilt.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward motion into the workspace (toward the neck) combined with a slight upward component. The positive Z-axis moves the end-effector closer into the neck region.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object (neck tissue) must move inward and slightly upward to allow the end-effector to apply gentle pressure and sliding contact motions.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to rightward sideways motion in the world frame (to the right side of the man's neck).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object (neck tissue) must move side-to-side gently from right to left, simulating a massage rubbing or kneading motion.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward and backward motion relative to the man’s neck and head orientation.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move along the neck length upward and downward with gentle pressure to simulate a comprehensive massaging stroke.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with small, repetitive oscillatory motions in the X and Y axes (side-to-side and up-and-down sliding over the neck surface), combined with a consistent moderate compression inward along the Z-axis (to maintain contact and massage pressure).

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive and negative forces alternately along the X-axis with magnitudes around ±5 N to enable smooth side-to-side stroking motions on the neck skin and muscles.

Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive and negative forces alternately along the Y-axis with magnitudes around ±3 N to achieve up-and-down gentle stroking along the neck length.

Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert a linear positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude approximately 10 N to maintain a gentle but firm grasp and compression on the neck without causing discomfort.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert no significant torque about the X-axis; rotational torque here is unnecessary as the massage focuses on linear stroking and compression.

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert a small angular torque clockwise about the Y-axis with magnitude about 1 N-m to subtly rotate and contour the gripper to the natural curvature of the neck during massage.

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert a small angular torque counterclockwise about the Z-axis with magnitude about 1 N-m to facilitate slight twisting motions for enhanced kneading effects.

Grasping force:  The neck skin and muscles are soft and sensitive but require moderate firm contact to feel effective. Considering skin friction coefficient ~0.5 and approximate local neck tissue mass negligible for support, a grasp force range of 8 to 12 N is appropriate to balance secure hold and user comfort.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Neck tissue: soft human skin and muscle, compliant cylindrical shape, friction coefficient ~0.5, negligible mass, requires gentle firm contact"

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Small oscillatory side-to-side (±0.01 m) along X, up-and-down (±0.008 m) along Y, and steady inward compression (~0.015 m) along Z over massage duration to simulate kneading and stroking"

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.01, 0.008, 0.015]

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5, 3, 10, 0, 1, -1]

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 10

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 120  # 2 minutes for thorough massage
```

[end of motion plan]

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
